revision.text:
{{oldafdfull| date = 7 February 2012 (UTC) | result = '''no consensus''' | page = Jet fighter generations }}
{{WPAVIATION|class=stub}} {{WPMILHIST|class=stub|Aviation=yes|Technology=yes}}
==Here's your ref!== Got a ref of great authority for the six generations.
It's by this guy
Richard P. Hallion (PhD, University of Maryland), of the Secretary of the Air Force's Action Group, was selected as the Charles A. Lindbergh Visiting Professor of Aerospace History for 1990-91 at the Smithsonian Institution.
And his generations are: * Me 262 * F-86 * MiG-19 * F-104 * F-4 * F-14
So the F-14 is officially a sixth generation jet fighter. Woot!
http://www.airpower.au.af.mil/airchronicles/apj/apj90/win90/1win90.htm
[[User:Hcobb|Hcobb]] ([[User talk:Hcobb|talk]]) 03:12, 15 January 2012 (UTC)
Awesome, thanks! [[User:Tjic|TJIC]] ([[User talk:Tjic|talk]]) 14:09, 7 February 2012 (UTC)
== sources reliability ==
This subject has always been difficult. Having [[WP:RS|reliable sources]] should help establish a clear and non objectionable classification. I have reviewed the ones present in the introduction : * {{citation |url=http://www.airpower.au.af.mil/airchronicles/apj/apj90/win90/1win90.htm |title=Air Force Fighter Acquisition since 1945 |author= Dr [[Richard P. Hallion]] |publisher= [[Air & Space Power Journal|Air Power Journal]] |date=Winter 1990 }} * {{cite web |url= http://www.eurofighter.com/fileadmin/web_data/downloads/extpub/02_5thGenFighter.pdf |archivedate= {{date|2012-11-02}} |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20121102122645/http://www.eurofighter.com/fileadmin/web_data/downloads/extpub/02_5thGenFighter.pdf |title= What is a 5th generationfighter |work= [[Eurofighter]] World |date= February 2010 |page= 16}} * {{Cite report |author= [[Daniel Slane]] |date= October 29, 2010 |title= 2010 Report to Congress |work= [[U.S.-China Economic and Security Review Commission]] |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=qU4uE-A1pUAC&pg=PA94&dq=%22fighter+generations%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=1eFUT4GhE8rTgQe4hsTpDQ&ved=0CDoQ6AEwAQ#v=snippet&q=%22generations%22&f=false |publisher= U.S. Government Printing Office |accessdate= 2012-03-15 }} and in each generation description : * {{cite book |author= [[Jim Winchester]] |editor= James Bennett |title=Jet Fighters Inside & Out |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=3shgcJXesN0C&pg=PA83&dq=%22fighter+generations%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=1eFUT4GhE8rTgQe4hsTpDQ&ved=0CD8Q6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=generations&f=false|series=Weapons of War |date=December 15, 2011 |publisher= [[The Rosen Publishing Group]] |location=New York |isbn= 978-1448859825 |pages= 5, 83}} * {{cite web |url= http://www.aerospaceweb.org/question/history/q0182.shtml |title= Fighter Generations |author= [[Joe Yoon]] |date= 27 June 2004 |publisher= [[Aerospaceweb]]}} * {{cite web |title= Fighter generations comparison chart |url= http://theaviationist.com/2011/01/13/fighter-generations-comparison-chart/|author= [[David Cenciotti]] |publisher= [[The Aviationist]] |date= 13 January 2011}} * {{cite web |title= Five Generations of Jet Fighter Aircraft |publisher= [[Royal Australian Air Force]] |work= Air Power Development Centre Bulletin |date= January 2012 |url= http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/publications/Details/475/170-Five-Generations-of-Jet-Fighter-Aircraft.aspx}}
[[Richard P. Hallion]] in [[Air & Space Power Journal|Air Power Journal]] is obviously a solid source, being notable enough to have his own article but at the end of the article there is the quote "The conclusions and opinions expressed in this document are those of the author [...] They do not reflect the official position of the U.S. Government, Department of Defense, the United States Air Force or the Air University."
The Eurofighter World article is a marketing text ("in-house propaganda" :) [http://www.flightglobal.com/blogs/the-dewline/2010/06/eurofighter-more-5th-gen-than/]), and is a good example on how a [[WP:Primary source]] could be distorted. As would be Lockheed Martin for the F-35.[https://www.f35.com/about]
The [[Daniel Slane]] report to the [[U.S.-China Economic and Security Review Commission]] isn't focused on the subject and use the aerospaceweb reference discussed below as a source (with an error on the name of the author), which isn't a good sign of credibility.
[[Jim Winchester]], while not being notable enough to have his bio in WP, is perhaps a good connoisseur of fighter jets, but this book is from a [[The Rosen Publishing Group|kid publisher]], which undermines its credibility.
The [[Aerospaceweb]] is [[WP:SELFPUBLISH|self-published]] by volunteers [http://www.aerospaceweb.org/about/], as is [[The Aviationist]] [http://theaviationist.com/about/] (even if they work in the field).
The [[Royal Australian Air Force|RAAF]] Air Power Development Centre Bulletin Article could be reliable but again at the end there is "The views expressed [...] are not necessarily those of the RAAF".
To sum up : two disclaimers, a marketing propaganda, a reference who quotes self publishing, a kid publishing company and two self-published sources. Not very good sources, even if most of them are knowledgeable and have clear ideas of a good classification. Better sources would be welcome. --[[User:Marc Lacoste|Marc Lacoste]] ([[User talk:Marc Lacoste|talk]]) 15:29, 13 May 2015 (UTC)
== how to make this encyclopedic ==
I worked pretty hard to make the concept more encyclopedic. Definitions can vary so much from one source to another. It's close to [[WP:OR]] in the X-generation articles when not listed aircrafts are included, it's too much US-centric (it's quasi [[century series]]-era, [[F-4]]-era, [[teen series]]-era), and sources are poor. A pretty good example of retrospective history : we try to make some sense of recent definitions, and [[WP:CIRCULAR]]. The worse part is it make some sense! There are obviously eras, and it help to compare between peers, but their boundaries are variable. The shift as defined by RAAF's bulletin as a when an innovation cannot be incorporated through upgrades is a neat idea. --[[User:Marc Lacoste|Marc Lacoste]] ([[User talk:Marc Lacoste|talk]]) 10:59, 15 May 2015 (UTC)
